title: Transfer Learning-Based Deep Residual Learning for Speech Recognition in Clean and Noisy Environments
author: Noussaiba Djeffal (University of Sciences and Technology, USTHB), Hamza Kheddar (University of MEDEA), Djamel Addou (University of Sciences and Technology, USTHB), Sid Ahmed Selouani (University of Moncton), ...
relevance_why: The paper presents a novel approach in enhancing speech recognition systems that could directly inform Dr. Liu's work on audio and speech processing, particularly in understanding the robustness of models in noisy environments.
background: The paper addresses automatic speech recognition (ASR) performance degradation caused by non-stationary environmental noise, proposing a deep learning model that improves recognition across various conditions.
contribution: This paper introduces a transfer learning framework using a Residual neural network (ResNet) for speech recognition in both clean and noisy environments, achieving significant accuracy improvements.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous speech recognition systems suffered from significant performance drops in noisy settings and often utilized basic convolutional models.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work enhances performance by employing a transfer learning approach with ResNet, which uses residual connections to maintain high accuracy even in challenging acoustic conditions.

key_innovation: Integrates a robust feature extraction frontend within an ASR framework, leveraging transfer learning from a pre-trained ResNet to enhance robustness against noise.
real_world_impact: The advancements made could encourage further usage of deep learning techniques in ubiquitous speech recognition applications, particularly in consumer electronics where noisy environments are common.
limitations: No specific limitations of the proposed model were mentioned in the paper.

new_terms.Residual neural network (ResNet): **Residual neural network (ResNet)** is a type of deep learning architecture that incorporates skip connections to enable training of deeper networks without suffering from vanishing gradient problems.
new_terms.Noise Robustness: **Noise robustness** refers to the ability of a system, especially ASR systems, to perform accurately despite the presence of external noise in the audio input.
